title: 112_s1339
content: The Act titled "Regulatory Information Reporting Act of 2011" requires reporting and compilation of participation data. The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "General Services Administration Office," "participant," "rule," and "rulemaking." Section 551(5) of title 5, United States Code defines how participants can represent economic, non-economic, or citizen interests in rulemaking processes. Participants in rulemaking processes can represent economic, non-economic, or citizen interests. Before a final rule is published in the Federal Register, the agency must submit a list of non-Federal Government participants who provided public comments, including their name, address, and organizational affiliation. The General Services Administration compiles participant information from rulemaking agencies into a searchable database available online. They also provide quarterly trend statistics publicly. The General Services Administration Office compiles data from rulemaking agencies into a searchable database and provides quarterly trend statistics publicly. They also submit annual reports to Congress summarizing the data with an emphasis on participation in the regulatory process by economic, non-economic, and citizen interests. The General Services Administration Office consults with the Administrative Conference of the United States as needed. The Administrator of General Services must create regulations within 90 days to implement this section. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment.
